quoteLast: is the great time for making business appointments. You meet your lawyer at one; you walk down to the office of the newspaper you may happen to write for, and settle the subject of your leading article, at one. One o’clock is a capital hour to step round to your stockbroker, in Pope’s Head Alley, Cornhill, and do a little business in stocks or shares. At one o’clock the Prime Minister, or his colleagues, have resignation enough to listen (with tolerable patience) to some half dozen deputations who come to harangue them about nothing in particular; at one o’clock obliging noblemen take the chair at public meetings at the Freemasons’, or the London Tavern.
title: Twice round the clock; or, The hours of the day and night in London
author: Sala, George Augustus, 1828-1895; McConnell, William, 1833-1867 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: We could not track a way across them. However, at 4 A.M. the next day, under the dexterous leading of Michel Croz, we passed the doubtful spot. Thence it was all plain sailing, and
quoteLast: we gained the summit. The weather was boisterous in the upper regions, and storm-clouds driven before the wind, and wrecked against our heights, enveloped us in misty spray, which danced around and fled away, which cut us off from the material universe, and caused us to be, as it were, suspended betwixt heaven and earth, seeing both occasionally, but seeming to belong to neither.
title: The Ascent of the Matterhorn
author: Whymper, Edward, 1840-1911

quoteFirst: Finally Pierre announced that he had incurred the "_peines pecunielles_" which were to be levied on his goods and lands "with moderation of justice." As for his crimes, for these he was to be hanged and burned, and that he might have opportunity to crave mercy of God, the time was fixed for
quoteLast: the next day. Gilles thanked him for the designation of the hour, adding that as he and his servants, Henriet and Poitou, had committed the crimes together, he asked that they might be executed together, so that he who was the cause of their guilt might admonish them, and show them the example of a good death, and by the grace of our Lord be the cause of their salvation.
title: A History of the Inquisition of the Middle Ages; volume III
author: Lea, Henry Charles, 1825-1909

quoteLast: he returned successful. He reached the wreck of the former party, making nine miles in three hours,--pushed on six miles further on the ice-foot,--then camped for the night; and, making a sturdy march the nest day without luggage, reached the huts, and got back to his camp to sleep.
